data.title: [RFC] Set `display: none` on hidden docks
data.body:
Sometimes, it's useful to be able to tell if your item is currently visible to the user or not. This can be used to back off of work, for example.

After talking to @nathansobo and @maxbrunsfeld, we decided the best way forward was to be able to use IntersectionObserver for this…but there are some issues.

The first is that—in its current iteration, at least—it doesn't seem to observe when visibility changes as a result of being masked by an `overflow: hidden` parent, which is how docks do it. (See [pen][1].)

To work around this, I put together this commit which toggles the `display` of the wrapper element when the dock is shown and completely masked. This guarantees that the IntersectionObserver will broadcast notifications at the appropriate time. However, this too has an issue: the `intersectionRatio` property (which I'd assume people would use to determine if the element was visible) is `0` at the beginning of the show animation. This kinda makes sense because, well, yeah, it isn't actually shown at all yet at the point when the animation to show it starts. I'm assuming that this is why the [`isIntersecting`][2] property was added (but I'm a n00b wrt the API so maybe not). After some playing around, though, I discovered that there was a way to distinguish between the visible and hidden states as, in the case of the item being shown, the `width + height` was nonzero.

So I wrote up some tests to verify the behavior and they pass…

but then I ran my tests without my dock changes and they still pass. That would seem to imply that the `overflow: hidden` masking _is_ actually triggering an IntersectionObserver notification?? 😖 (It doesn't if you observe the tree view and toggle the dock.)

@nathansobo @as-cii Any guidance you could give about this inconsistent IntersectionObserver behavior would be super appreciated.

[1]: https://codepen.io/matthewwithanm/pen/LLpypJ
[2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IntersectionObserverEntry/isIntersecting

data.title: Don't recreate Atom shortcut on Desktop on update
data.body:
This PR updates the Squirrel hooks to tell Squirrel.Windows directly what kinds of shortcuts to create on update instead of creating them then deleting after-the-fact

Fixes #5323

## TODO:

- [x] Make sure this works

data.title: Redirect outdated links in keymap.cson
data.body:
When I open the Keymap.cson file, the links provided are outdated.

```
# You can find more information about keymaps in these guides:
# * https://atom.io/docs/latest/using-atom-basic-customization#customizing-key-bindings
# * https://atom.io/docs/latest/behind-atom-keymaps-in-depth
```

They just redirect to the root of http://flight-manual.atom.io/.

data.title: Add key binding for unbound commands is difficult
data.body:
Today I wanted to add a key binding for the "Toggle Soft Wrap" command. It was unclear to me how I'd do that.

I went to `Settings` > `Keybindings` but it only shows bindings for commands that are already bound.
I tried `CTRL+.` (`CMD+,` on Mac) which shows bindings for shortcuts invoked. I hoped maybe it'd show me the potential binding if I invoked the `Toggle Soft Wrap` menu. No luck.

So of course, I go to Google and @maxbrunsfeld answered [the question here](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5962).

```
'atom-text-editor':
  'f10': 'editor:toggle-soft-wrap'
```

That's great, but I can't rely on Max having answered that question for every binding I may want to set.

Would be nice to have `Keybindings` show unbound commands too (perhaps in a separate tab or at the end of the list). Or have it allow you to search. Or perhaps have a way to invoke a tooltip on menu items  that show you the name of the item for key binding. Many ways to address the problem.

data.title: Entire IDE window flickers uncontrollably, can't use Atom on this machine
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Upon starting the IDE, it flickers uncontrollably, at a high framerate. 

### Steps to Reproduce

atom . (in any folder)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

(normal IDE behavior with no flickering)

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Uncontrollably flickering of the entire app window.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Every single time.

### Versions
atom --version
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1

Linux Mint 17, qiana (ubuntu 14.04 base kernel)

### Additional Information

Here's my notes, so far... Please help stop the flicker?

(NOTES BELOW) 

I'm hoping someone here might be able to point me towards a resolution for a flicker issue with qt on desktop linux mint 17 machine running in dual monitor mode. I'm not sure if ALL QT apps are flickering uncontrollably, or just some. Specifically, if I start "zoom", a video chat app, another QT flickering app, I see such things as this: 

   If I do:
        export QSG_INFO=1
        zoom

I see:

QSG_RENDER_LOOP is

qt.scenegraph.general: Max Texture Size:  16384
qt.scenegraph.general: Debug context:     false
Error: Send error, 22 Invalid argument
Error: Send error, 22 Invalid argument
Error: Send error, 22 Invalid argument


   At this point the screen draws the app, but it is filled with black, or it is filled with the image that was already on the screen before the app was drawn. If I move my mouse over the app, or move it around on the screen, it flickers, and I can momentarily see the app, during the half-flicker states, lol.

   I've tried some things to remedy this, to no avail, such as:

(updating to newest version of QT)
export QT_SELECT=5
qmake -v
   QMake version 3.0
   Using Qt version 5.2.1 in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu

export QT_OPENGL=angle
export QT_ANGLE_PLATFORM=d3d9
export QT_OPENGL=software
export LIBGL_ALWAYS_SOFTWARE=1
export QSG_RENDER_LOOP=basic
export FB_MULTI_BUFFER=2
export FB_MULTI_BUFFER=3
(installing / updating dependencies listed for ubuntu os via apt-get)
(gleaned info from here but nothing useful so far: [url]http://blog.qt.io/blog/2017/01/18/opengl-implementation-qt-quick-app-using-today/[/url])

I noticed my two monitors have two different refresh rates, changing them to both be at 60hz seemed to make no difference...

Any other ideas on how to troubleshoot this?

data.title: Appveyor switch to Node 6.9.4 from 6.8.0
Best performance by removing  some parts of chrome.
data.body:
Atom is very good and very beautiful editor.Howewer, it has some performance problems.
Previous releases was shipped wit such things like 64bit architecture support, better handling of large and minifed files.

I think performance can be hugely improved if from atom will removed such parts of chrome like:
console, viewing of current code and all devtools. This things is unneeded and they slow up editors in meny ways. I thing it will be a good approach if atom will use only interpraing engine for languages, and other  minimal toolset.

data.title: Prevent block decorations from mistakenly wrapping during measurements
data.body:
Fixes #14743.

Before rendering block decorations, we read their heights by putting them into a special div called `blockDecorationMeasurementsArea`.

Previously, this div was not explicitly sized, which was causing decorations to wrap while being measured but not when actually rendering them.

This pull-request fixes this inconsistency by explicitly styling the measurement area so that it has the same width as the component scroll width.

/cc: @atom/maintainers @t9md

data.title: File removed outside of Atom does not close tab in Atom
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Let's say I have a git repo with a single file, `a.txt`, on `master`.  The `add-b-file` branch adds a new `b.txt` file to the repo.  When on `add-b-file` with both `a.txt` and `b.txt` open in Atom, switching branches to `master` does not close `b.txt` even if there are no unsaved changes.  I have "Close Deleted File Tabs" checked.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a git repo and commit a file
2. Switch to a new branch and add a different file
3. Open both files in Atom
4. Switch back to the original branch

**Expected behavior:** Only `a.txt` to exist in Atom

**Actual behavior:** Both files are still open, with `b.txt` marked as having unsaved changes.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
```
Atom    : 1.19.0-dev-c6bf86c9b
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

This looks like a regression from #693.  The steps to reproduce I gave are what I believe to be a simplified version of what I'm experiencing.  If they don't actually work, the actual scenario I'm facing has to do with switching between the `wl-split-grammars` and `master` branch on atom/language-php.

Tentatively /cc'ing @iolsen because of atom/tabs#306.

data.title: Nested git repo is ignored by fuzzy finder when "Exclude VCS Ignored Paths" checked
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Checking out a git repo inside another git repo while "Exclude VCS Ignored Paths"  is turned on ignores all files inside the nested repo when searching in the fuzzy finder. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. git clone git@github.com:llvm-mirror/llvm.git
2. cd llvm/tools
3. git clone git@github.com:llvm-mirror/clang.git
4. add project folder <path to llvm> in atom
5. See that llvm/tools/clang is greyed out
6. ctrl + p (open fuzzy finder), search "driver.cpp"
7. See no file found
8. Open preferences, disable "Exclude VCS Ignored Paths"
9. See llvm/tools/clang still greyed out
10. ctrl + p (open fuzzy finder), search "driver.cpp"
11. See that llvm/tools/clang/tools/driver/driver.cpp is found

(Sorry for the choice of llvm/clang, I realize they're big repos but they're also a concrete example)

**Expected behavior:** 
The nested repo should not be greyed out nor missing from fuzzy finder when "Exclude VCS Ignored Paths" is on, only its .gitignore should be applied.

**Actual behavior:**
The nested repo remains greyed out no matter what, but if the option is disabled then the files are available in the fuzzy finder.

**Reproduces how often:** 
100%.

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

`atom --version`
```Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

`apm --version`
```apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

OS
```Ubuntu 16.04.2 LTS
Linux 4.4.0-79-generic #100-Ubuntu SMP Wed May 17 19:58:14 UTC 2017 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```


### Additional Information
Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
I'm not sure what else is needed, will provide when asked though.

data.title: Bottom dock focus issue
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode
* Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide
* Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions
* Checked that the issue isn't already filed (This was actually posted as a comment in #14439)
* Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality

### Description
There is a series of problem with focus on the bottom dock.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install a package that belongs to the bottom dock (to explain all the different problems I'll use [atom-terminal-tab](https://atom.io/packages/atom-terminal-tab) and [linter-ui-default](https://atom.io/packages/linter-ui-default))
2. Manually open the bottom dog with the Up arrow displayed on hover
3. Type some text. **First issue:** The editor still has focus, I would expect the dock to have focus since I manually opened it.
4. Click the dock to give it focus. Now you can type in the dock
5. Now try to switch to the Linter dock. **Second issue:** The docks closes automatically giving focus back to the editor (Note in order to replicate this issue there should be no linter errors and `Hide Panel When Empty` should be enabled in linter-ui-default configuration)

I experienced more issues before that I can no longer replicate, like for example clicking inside the dock gave focus to the dock but it also closed it, so when you typed the text went to the dock but you couldn't see it. This has been fixed since (maybe in Atom 1.18 beta 3 or in the Terminal package)

The second issue probably belongs to @steelbrain /linter-ui-default so I would like to focus on the first issue since that is a problem with Atom itself.

**Actual behavior:**
![atom-bottom-dock-focus-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1095969/27061083-ae6ce58c-4fb7-11e7-8e87-bda9f16f17a9.gif)

**Reproduces how often:**
Always

### Versions
I'm running on Atom 1.18 beta 3 (Windows 10 x64) but have replicated back to Atom 1.17 beta 0 when docks were first introduced.

### Additional Information
```
Atom  1.18.0-beta3
Electron  1.3.15
Chrome  52.0.2743.82
Node  6.5.0
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node  6.9.5 x64
python  2.7.13
git  2.13.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

data.title: Update CSP to allow using eval from JavaScript
data.body:
### Description of the Change

While attempting to interact with an Express.js server within some Atom tests, we ran into the following error related to Atom's current Content Security Policy:

```
EvalError: Refused to evaluate a string as JavaScript because 'unsafe-eval' is not an allowed source of script in the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src 'self'".

  at Function.wrapfunction [as function] (node_modules/depd/index.js:409:43)
  at populateConstructorExports (node_modules/http-errors/index.js:247:45)
  at Object.<anonymous> (node_modules/http-errors/index.js:29:1)
  at Object.<anonymous> (node_modules/http-errors/index.js:262:3)
```

This PR updates the policy to resolve this error ☝️, allowing Atom to run [this code](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2988/27043798-58b9ed04-4f69-11e7-80e8-3db5f8336cd5.png).

### Alternate Designs

We could have changed Express.js's dependencies to stop using eval, but we are not aware of any advantages of making such a change upstream.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

N/A

### Benefits

Allow package authors to use libraries that rely on eval.

### Possible Drawbacks

We're not aware of any negative consequences that this change would introduce, but it _is_ a change to the CSP, so we definitely want to hear from others. :pray:

@atom/maintainers: Do you know of any negative consequences that would result from this change?

### Applicable Issues

N/A

data.title: Pulling the tracking git branch via UI causes error
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Doing git pull via the new Atom UI (pressing the "down arrow" button in the bottom-right corner, and then pressing "Pull" button) causes the following error:

Unable to pull
fatal: Couldn't find remote ref my-local-branch-name

Doing the 'git pull' from the command line works fine.

Please note that there is no 'my-local-branch-name' on the server indeed, the remote branch name is different, but the local branch is set to track that remote branch, let's call it "my-remote-branch".

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions
Atom    : 1.18.0-beta3
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Let me know if you need more info (and how to get that info).

data.title: Spellcheck on file tree view items
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Spell check seems to be active for items in the file tree view, which isn't necessary. Can we deactivate spell check for the tree view? 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Select a file in the tree view

![screen shot 2017-06-12 at 14 31 40](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4557648/27019486-42487d7a-4f7c-11e7-8996-8804a348a7de.png)


**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Spell checking not necessary in tree view

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

### Versions

Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.10.1

MacOS 10.12.5

data.title: Cant download for windows 10 why
data.body:
When The atom setup fineshed i started it up and it did not came up the installer
then i went and found the atominstaller file and double clicked it and then it said :
'This app can't run on your PC
To find a version for your Pc, Check with the software publisher."
Please help i need it for Coding i really like your editer so i had it in my older computer and now i got a new computer so i re-download it but it cant be done 
sorry for the bad english iam rubbish at english
